## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 301, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 255, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 515, 359, 530]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 210, 146, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 870, 229]]<|/det|>
Fig. 10.1 shows the proposed system for charging the battery of an electric toothbrush.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 235, 821, 658]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 673, 537, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 704, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
The handle of the brush contains the battery and a coil X. The circuit from coil X to the battery is not shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 750, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
The base of the charger contains a coil Y, wound on an iron core, connected to the a.c. mains supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 797, 756, 814]]<|/det|>
To charge the battery, the handle is lowered so that coil Y is inside coil X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 776, 845]]<|/det|>
Fig. 10.1 shows the direction needed for the charging current at the battery.

<label>(i)</label>

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 697, 92]]<|/det|>
The radioactive isotope carbon-14 ( \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C})\) emits \(\beta \)-particles as it decays.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 655, 121]]<|/det|>
The decay of carbon-14 produces an isotope of nitrogen (N).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 133, 705, 152]]<|/det|>
State the nature of a \(\beta \)-particle and state where it is produced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 193, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 225, 181, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 225, 769, 243]]<|/det|>
Complete the nuclide equation for the radioactive decay of carbon-14.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 247, 653, 278]]<|/det|>
\[^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\quad \rightarrow \quad \mathrm {^{....}N}\quad +\quad \mathrm {^{....}B}\]

<mark>[3]

The half-life of carbon-14 is 5700 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 507, 338]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
A workman operates a machine that uses \(\beta \)-particles to determine the level of liquid in a plastic water bottle that is being filled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 267, 477]]<|/det|>
Suggest why

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 180, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 490, 604, 508]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha \)-particles are not suitable for the same purpose,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 549, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 581, 180, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 581, 566, 600]]<|/det|>
